p: Influenza is a respiratory infection of serious public health concern, with over three million cases of severe influenza-associated illness reported globally each year [ 1]. In temperate climates, epidemics occur each winter and leave signatures of spatial spread that are still not fully understood [ 2– 4]. A rich literature from countries with historically available data, such as the United States (US) and France, associates such signatures with spatial distributions of population density, specific humidity conditions, and human movements [ 5– 9]. However, to understand the true extent of these associations, analyses must be extrapolated across a greater range of demographic and climatic environments.
